title: 111_s2927
content: The "Wall Street Fair Share Act" includes a new subchapter in the Internal Revenue Code for a tax on securities transactions. The "Wall Street Fair Share Act" imposes a tax on covered transactions with securities at a rate of 0.25 percent of the fair market value. Different rates apply to derivatives and short-term debt instruments. The "Wall Street Fair Share Act" imposes a tax on covered transactions with securities at a rate of 0.02 percent of the fair market value for securities with a fixed maturity date not exceeding 1 year. Hedging transactions have a tax rate of 0.02 percent. A covered transaction is defined as any purchase on a U.S. trading facility. The "Wall Street Fair Share Act" imposes a tax on covered transactions with securities at a rate of 0.02 percent of the fair market value for securities with a fixed maturity date not exceeding 1 year. Covered transactions include any purchase on a U.S. trading facility involving a security where the purchaser or seller is a United States person, or if the transaction is facilitated by a United States person. The "Wall Street Fair Share Act" imposes a tax on covered transactions with securities at a rate of 0.02 percent of the fair market value for securities with a fixed maturity date not exceeding 1 year. Covered transactions include any purchase on a U.S. trading facility involving a security where the purchaser or seller is a United States person, or if the transaction is facilitated by a United States person. The Act defines derivative financial instruments as options, forward contracts, short positions, notional principal contracts, credit default swaps, or similar financial instruments. It also defines specified index as any combination of securities, indexes, or other financial instruments. The "Wall Street Fair Share Act" imposes a tax on covered transactions with securities based on objectively determinable information not controlled by the parties. Exceptions include no tax on initial security issuance and securities held in retirement accounts. The tax imposed under the "Wall Street Fair Share Act" does not apply to certain mutual fund transactions involving regulated investment companies owned by specific retirement accounts. The tax imposed by the "Wall Street Fair Share Act" does not apply to certain mutual fund transactions involving regulated investment companies owned by specific retirement accounts. The tax shall be paid by the trading facility in the US or the broker for transactions executed elsewhere. The "Wall Street Fair Share Act" tax does not apply to certain mutual fund transactions involving regulated investment companies owned by specific retirement accounts. The Secretary, in consultation with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, administers the withholding requirements for foreign purchasers. The Secretary also provides guidance on information reporting for covered transactions. The Secretary administers withholding requirements for foreign purchasers and provides guidance on information reporting for covered transactions, including regulations to prevent avoidance of tax purposes. A new section is added for a credit on the first $100,000 of stock transactions per year. The new section allows individuals to claim a credit against the tax for securities transactions, with a maximum credit of $250 ($125 for married individuals filing separately). Definitions align with those in section 4475, and a new withholding section is added for securities transactions. In outbound securities transactions, a tax must be deducted and withheld, with exceptions for derivatives. The term 'outbound securities transaction' refers to covered transactions not occurring on a US trading facility, with the purchaser not being a US person. Conforming amendments are made to the tax code. Conforming amendments are made to the tax code, including inserting "36B," after "36A," in certain sections. Additionally, clerical amendments are made to the table of subchapters for chapter 36 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax code is amended to include withholding on securities transactions and a credit for securities transaction taxes. These amendments apply to transactions after December 31, 2010.
